Entry.1:
On our way back from Kits 139. With kit bags Passed 3rd Brigade

Had a swim

Saw Dave in distance
Entry.2:
1917

Paraded re transfer out of No 1 Coy.

Wed 17 1917

Went down to see Dave Roth. He looks well. Trying to get me to the 10th LH

Thurs 18 1917

Transfer went in just waiting for reply 

Friday January 1917

Jan 19th 1917

Supper Sargents. J R. Paper train to camp

January 1917

Sunday

First quiet day since arriving in El Arish. Wrote several letters.

Monday 22 17

Frightfully windy sand flying in every direction

JR Birthday

January 25 

Sate de Danse

Dirige Par

Mr Sindicas (near cosmography

Sate de Danse

Rue Boulac

Mons,Mosssery

(near Petrograd)

Sunday 11 1917

Left No 1 Coy ICC 10 am . Joined 10th A.L.H. Reverted to rank of trooper at own request.

Saw Dave Roth both afternoon and night

February 1917

Monday

Met Father Goodman MM

He is RC chaplain to 10th batt

Tues 13 1917

Went over to 2nd Brigade. Saw lot of 7 ALH boys. Met J McAuliffe

March Saturday 11 1916

Sailed away in Orsova A67 from Sydney.

First day at sea lovely weather. Ocean like glass. Fine boat. Well looked after

Sunday 12 1916

Went to mass. Fr McAuliffe on board. Good trip so far
Entry.3:
Arrived in Port Melbourne 9 am or thereabouts.

Landed. Went for a March. Went into Melb 6.30. Had good look round. Taxis – fares and attention changed. Rather amused with attention added to the fare.
Entry.4: Still in Melb. Had route March through city to Royal Park and back to boat. People unenthusiastic. Cold and distant. Went in to Melb again in the night . Went to Tivoli.
Entry.5:
March to Albert Park, guests of Red Cross Ladies. Excellent lunch. I had lovely 20 mile drive in car. Back to Melb at 1.30 special leave to purchase .

Saw the block and the styles. Girls smostly done up, but still cold and distant.
Entry.6: Left Melb at 3pm for Colombo. Only got 1 wine from home. No letters or word from anyone else. Aust Flying Squadron joined us here before leaving
Entry.7: At sea, good weather and fine trip. Appointed Sgt Major for trip. Also on sports committee for trip.
Entry.10:
Good weather making a good passage.

Orsova a lovely ship.

 

March	 1916
Entry.11: Arrived Freemantle 9pm. Anchored in stream. No one allowed ashore
Entry.12:
(Had sport meeting)

Left Freemantle 12 noon after 14 hours stay. Sent mail ashore. Saw Freemantle newspaper.
Entry.13:
Boxing tourney.

Good sport and bouts keenly contested.

O.C. troops is one of the best. He is Lt Col Nicholson (of Newcastle)
Entry.18:
Sports.

Lt J.P.G.Cox and self are secretaries. We are able to hold 75 yd sprint straight.
Entry.19: Mails closed 5 pm today will be sent ashore at Colombo
Entry.21:
Medical lecture

Saturday April 1

Arrived Colombo 6am. Got ashore 3.45 pm. Marched to barracks (40 min) Stayed G.O.H. Went all around also to Circus.

Beautiful sight coming in breakwater, natives very interesting .Very hot.
Entry.22:
Visited sights of Colombo in rickshaw. Temple,Galle Face. Park Gardens. Bought silk at native shops. Spent £2-5-0.

Thoroughly enjoyed stay. Cost 15/- for 2 days, very cheap

Left Colombo 10.30 pm
Entry.23: Wrote long letters about Colombo . Small monkey brought aboard from Colombo. Pet of the ship
Entry.24:
Boxing contests

Flying fish still plentiful sea like glass
Entry.25:
Off Persian Gulf 

Very smooth trip
Entry.27: In the Red Sea very very hot.
Entry.28: Arrived at Suez. A khamseem was blowing and the dust like a dense fog so we anchored until tomorrow
Entry.29: Sunrise most gorgeous no wonder they write of the wonderful colourings of Egypt. Left Suez 2pm for Tel el Kebir, some in cattle trucks . Arrived at 8pm. (in the desert). Moonlight Marched 1½ miles to our camp very chilly
Entry.30: Had a look at the desert. Bare barren and sandy. Les Spragg,Tom Reid, Reg King, Barrett and Montring to see me. Vic Masters also
Entry.31:
Went to Cairo with Vic Masters. Shall never forget my first day in Cairo went to Pyramids and Sphinx and all round Cairo.

The Mousski is the most interesting part of Cairo.
Entry.33: Anzac Day – Holiday Sports etc at Tel el Kebir
Entry.35: Tel el Kebir camp work, heart, dust sand and more work. An absolute nightmare will be glad when I can get out to the regiment.
Entry.36: Nothing doing in L.H. scrapping so the drill goes on day after day
Entry.39:
Tel el Kebir

Drill and usual routine nothing worth recording
Entry.40: Left Tel el Kebir 5.45 pm mounted for Moascar
Entry.42:
Bathing parade Great Lakes, Ismaelia, Suez Canal.

HMS Euryalus anchored in Canal.
Entry.43:
Went to Ismaelia. Pretty town

Conditions at Moascar are far better than Tel el Kebir.
Entry.44: Was transferred to Imperial Camel Corps Austn Reserves, Abbassia, Cairo
Entry.46:
Best home I have been in since I joined the military viz the I.C.C. Abbassia (Aust Reserves)

Fine lot of fellows, the other sergts. Especially SSM Robertson (SA) Sergt (now) Lieut Williams N.S.W.
Entry.47: Easy work – plenty of leave – trips to Cairo.
Entry.48:
Plenty of camel drill

Some very amusing incidents occurring every day.
Entry.49: Met Hughes Hiddelston Sgt A.P.C. friend of Muriel Roberts. Went to Arabic wedding on his invitation. Funniest experience I have had.
Entry.50:
Left Abbassia with 39 men 8.30am to join No 1 Coy ICC . Arrived Gara on the Nile 9.30pm

Camped the night Beautiful scenery down the Nile which was in flood.
Entry.51: Left Qara 8.30am for the 150 or so miles across the desert . Train broke down at 12 noon after climbing the escarp. Another engine sent on and we left at 12 MN arrived Sherika 6 am Sunday . No camels for my section so will have to wait.
Entry.52: We formed the full comp` to a company of camel Corps . 180 strong.
Entry.53:
Sherika is an oasis in Libyan desert – very fertile on the oasis but bare and barren away from it. 

Settling down to camp routine.
Entry.54: Capt Wright (an Englishman) is O.C. and is a peculiar man. Has several favourites in the Coy. He does not seem to like Australians. Lt. Grime one of the officers is a most useless fool. Lt Mills seems a decent chap and capable.
Entry.55: Two sections under Lieut Mills moved out to occupy Dahkla Oasis, about 80 miles from Khargah Oasis.
Entry.57: Another section went to reinforce other two sections at Dabkla
Entry.58: Dahkla taken with the 175 Senussi prisoners. Main body of Senussi got away aided by spies. Camels knocked up so unable to chase them
Entry.60: now with Flying Corps – at Sherika
Entry.61: Met 3 Sergts from Flying Corps who came over on Orsova with me
Entry.62: Went over to Flying Corps. Had a machine explained to me.
Entry.63:
Went out per camel towards Temple of Hibis in Kharga Oasis. 9½ miles. 

Did not get to Temple but saw the remains of an ancient cottage. Started to get dark, so the officers wanted to get back. Quite dark before arriving in camp. Journey 2½ hours each way on rotten camel.
Entry.65:
and Monday 12 and 13

Dream,dream, of her who awaits an enveloping attack of you.
Entry.66: Shooting on range tons of work
Entry.68: Fatigues for the Coy which is coming in from Dahkla
Entry.69:
Shooting again

I put up very poor score. Eyes played up. Cold hardly see target.
Entry.70: Erecting tents for remainder of coy
Entry.71: Big mail from Australia arrived. 20 letters, pcl and papers.
Entry.72: Left Sherika with 10 men to act as escort to convoy CTC from Khargeb to Tenida (Dahkla oasis) at 2.23. visited ruined city, saw mummies,visited Temple of Hibis, date 2000B.C. or so in the Persian dynasty. Wonderful carvings on stone walls. Arrived Khargeh about 6 pm.
Entry.73:
Bought 100 oranges for trip.

Breakfasted CTC. Train with Senussi prisoners arrived from Dahkla 10.30am. Took snaps. Visited village in afternoon. Very interesting cultivation prolific. Mud houses mostly underground. Filthy hovels .Visited the Omla who gave us afternoon tea English style. Had a swim in big fresh pool of unknown depth. We leave tomorrow.
Entry.74: Left 7.30 am with the convoy of 200 camels and about 80 natives.
Entry.77: Arrived near the oasis of Dahkla at dark. Halted for night. Will go in to the village of Tenida in the morning.
Entry.78:
Arrived in Tenida 7am Went down the village bought eggs. Residents very poor. Senussis robbed of everything.

 

Nov-Dec 1916
Entry.79: Went down the village – got more eggs for tea and sugar
Entry.80:
Dec.1

Left for the return journey.
Entry.81: Still travelling back pleasant weather but very hot in day and cold at night.
Entry.83: Left for Sherika and got back to camp 12noon.feeling very fit.
Entry.84: Got word No.1 Coy to leave Sherika tomorrow to concentrate at Gara. Probably to go to the Canal.
Entry.85: 3 sections left per camel for Gara 110 miles. 2pm
Entry.89:
Arrived in camp Gara 11 am

Leaving here for Kantara on the canal on Thursday
Entry.90: Busy getting ready for our long trek. Our probable destination is El Arish.
Entry.91: Everything ready for leaving tomorrow wrote several letters.
Entry.92: Left Gara per camel for oasis junction. 5 miles entrained camels and baggage and left at 4 oclock for Cairo
Entry.93: Arrived Cairo station 1030 am had lunch and left for Kantara at 11.30. Passed thro` Tel el Kebir Moascar Ismaelia and arrived Kantara about 5pm. Unloaded camels and baggage and camped for the night.
Entry.94:
Started on our long trek 7am.Passed several graves of L.H. on the journey saw lots of dead horses.

Arrived at Duedar and camped for the night. There was a battle here last Easter Sunday between LH and the Turk. The LH held out ; numerous graves.
Entry.95:
Left very early. Passed thro Katia and then 5 miles south of Romani. 

Still seeing graves.
Entry.97: Getting ready to move off to the scene of action. Fixing up camels and rations and saddles
Entry.98: Left Mazar 2.30pm arrived Kilo (?) 7 pm had tea and pushed on thro the night. Awful journey (rough) fell down sandhill with camel.
Entry.99: Arrived El Arish 8.30 am camped outside the town about 5 miles away. L.H. captured the town.
Entry.100:
All day in camp El Arish

Moved out 9.20 pm Travelled all night, very cold arrived scene of battle 8am. L.H. scouts and advance guards in touch with enemy.
Entry.101: The battle of Magdaba My No.1 Section – No 1 Coy led by Lt Williams DCM led the Camel Corps into action very tired sleepy and hungry went to sleep under fire battle lasted all day. Turks surrended 1283 prisoners numerous guns rifle and ammo. We had 6 casualties. Lt Williams
Entry.102:
Back in camp El Arish resting after the battle.

Rained during night everything wet also everybody – very cold.

Monday 25
Entry.103:
Wet and cold and miserable. Bully biscuits for dinner.

Acting QM. Trying to keep dry which is impossible.
Entry.104:
Wet and cold

Work early and late

River appeared in the wadi caused by rain from the hills.
Entry.105:
Wet again also very cold plenty of work

Drawing rations from the beach - 2½ miles away. Rations are brought up in steamers and sent ashore in boats.
Entry.107:
Showery weather, went down to the beach. Great load of stores. Landed from steamers

Mine sweeper ashore last night.
Entry.108:
Squally weather

Sunday 31

Terrific gale blowing no shelter. Everybody wet. Rained during night
Entry.109:
. All 1917

Went down to beach bombarded by German Taubs. 3 shells fell down into the sea. Remainder went into palm groves. 13 casualties amongst British troops. Terrific wind blowing. Had the coldest swim I ever had.

Notes For 1917
Entry.110: Nothing doing very squally and showery
Entry.111: Still raining wet blankets every night. Expecting to have colds and rheumatism. Well so far ordinary routine of camp. Rumours of big battle to come off at Rhafa.
Entry.112:
Plenty of work at QMs job. Fine day very cold

Memoranda
Entry.113: Rained again in showers. Wind very cold. Met a lot of old friends. Lt Lamb, Lt Dawson
Entry.114: LH Lt Bell 2 LH all in
Entry.117: Work very hard today all bustle whilst issuing rations at 8 pm moonlight our camp was bombed by Taubs 2 bombs dropped 30 yards away. No damage. Moving out to Rafa for battle tomorrow.
